document.docTitle: Lanostane triterpenoids from cultivated fruiting bodies of Ganoderma sichuanense: Determination of the C-25 absolute configuration of ganoderic acid A and its derivatives using the phenylglycine methyl ester (PGME) method

paragraph.docTitle:
Lanostane triterpenoids from cultivated fruiting bodies of
Ganoderma
sichuanense : Determination
of the C-25 absolute configuration of ganoderic acid A and its derivatives using the phenylglycine methyl ester (PGME) method

Panida Chinthanom a

paragraph.emphasis: National Biobank of Thailand , 114 Thailand Science Park, Phaholyothin Road, Klong Luang, Pathumthani, 12120, Thailand

School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, South-Central University for Nationalities, Wuhan, 430074, People ’

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Lanostane triterpenoids
PGME method
Antitubercular activity
A B S T R A C T

Three undescribed lanostane triterpenoids, together with twenty-one known compounds, were isolated from artificially cultivated fruiting bodies of the basidiomycete
Ganoderma sichuanense
. The absolute configuration at C-25 of ganoderic acid A and its derivatives was determined to be 25 R by application of the phenylglycine methyl ester (PGME) method. Among the isolated compounds, ganoderiol F exhibited the most potent activity against
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
H37Ra with an MIC value of 0.781 μg/ml.

Medicinal mushrooms of the genus
Ganoderma
have been used for many types of health products. Lanostane triterpenoids have been considered one of the key ingredients of
Ganoderma lucidum
, a popular traditional Chinese medicine known as Lingzhi , and related species of the
Ganoderma lucidum
complex ( Zhou et al., 2015 ). A number of lanostanes and modified lanostanes have been isolated from these species (Baby et al., 2015; Xia et al., 2014 ), and a broad range of their biological activities linked to the health-improving properties of the medicinal mushroom have been reported ( Paterson, 2006 ). Recently , we conducted artificial fruiting body cultivation of various
Ganoderma species
and their chemical investigations as a strategy for structural diversification of
Ganoderma
lanostanoids ( Isaka et al., 2020a , 2020b , 2020c ). We report here the results of the chemical investigation of a Lingzhi –like
Ganoderma species
collected in Northern Thailand , which was identified as
Ganoderma sichuanense J.D. Zhao & X.Q. Zhang (Ganodermataceae)
after performing the chemical studies. This species is considered one of the members of the
Ganoderma lucidum
complex. Three undescribed lanostane triterpenoids ( 1–3 ) ( Fig. 1 ), together with twenty-one known lanostanes ( 4–24 ) (
Fig. S 1
), were isolated from the cultivated fruiting bodies. The isolated compounds were tested for antitubercular and antimalarial activities and cytotoxicity to noncancerous Vero cells. We also report here the determination of the C-25 absolute configuration of ganoderic acid A ( 4 ) and structurally close analogs by using the phenylglycine methyl ester (PGME) method ( Yabuuchi and Kusumi, 2000 ).

The molecular formula of compound 1 was determined by HRESIMS and 13 C NMR as C 33 H 48 O 7 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR, DEPT, and HSQC data for 1 supported the presence of three ketones, a carboxyl carbon, a tetrasubstituted olefin, a ketal carbon, two oxygenated methines, four quaternary carbons, four methines, seven methylenes, and nine methyl groups ( Table 1 ). The NMR data were similar to those of the well-known cometabolite ganoderic acid A ( 4 ) ( Kubota et al., 1982 ); however, compound 1 additionally possessed a ketal carbon ( δ C 102.1) and two singlet methyl groups. The lanostane C 30 skeleton was proven to be the same as ganoderic acid A by analysis of COSY and HMBC spectra ( Fig. 2 ). Thus, the locations of the three ketones at C-3, C-11, and C-23 were revealed by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -1, H 2 -2, H 3 -28, and H 3 -29 to C-3 ( δ C 217.1), from H 2 -12 to C-11 ( δ C 199.6), and from H 2 -22 and H 2 -24 to C-23 ( δ C 208.5), respectively. The presence of a terminal carboxylic acid was demonstrated by the HMBC correlations from Ha- 24, Hb- 24, H-25, and H 3 -27 to the carbonyl carbon ( δ C 180.6, C-26). The presence of an acetonide that links 7β- OH and 15α- OH of ganoderic acid A was revealed by the HMBC correlations from H-7 ( δ H 4.58), H-15 ( δ H 4.53), and singlet methyl protons H 3 -1 ʹ ( δ H 1.45) and H 3 -3 ʹ ( δ H 1.37) to the ketal carbon (C-2 ʹ ). The relative configuration of compound 1 was elucidated to be the same as ganoderic acid A on the basis of the NOESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ). Correlations between H 3 -19/ Hβ- 6, Hα- 6/H-7, and H-7/H 3 -30 demonstrated a trans AB-ring junction and an α- orientation of H-7. The relative configuration of C-13/C-14/C-15/C-17/C-20 was deduced from the NOESY correlations between H 3 -30/ Hα- 12, H 3 -30/H-17, H 3 -18/ Hβ- 12, H 3 -18/H-15, H 3 -18/H-20, and Hβ- 12/H 3 -21. NOESY correlations of H-7/H 3 -1 ʹ and H-15/H 3 -3 ʹ were consistent with the trans relation of H-7 (α) and H-15 (β). The structure of compound 1 was confirmed by chemical correlation to ganoderic acid A ( 4 ). Compound 4 was converted to 1 by treatment with p -TsOH‧H 2 O in 2,2-dimethoxypropane. Consequently, compound 1 was identified as the acetonide derivative of ganoderic acid A. In the present study, the mushroom material was extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 and MeOH; however, acetone was used for silica gel column chromatography (see Experimental). Therefore, the possibility that compound 1 was an isolation artifact resulting from acetonide formation from 4 is not ruled out.
* Corresponding author.
E-mail address: isaka@biotec.or.th (M. Isaka).

The remaining question was the absolute configuration of C-25. Ganoderic acid A ( 4 ) is one of the major lanostane constituents in the medicinal mushroom Lingzhi (
G. lucidum
), and it is the first member of a large compound group with the trivial name. Therefore, it has been recognized as a symbolic
Ganoderma
lanostanoid. The structure of the C-20–C-27 side chain, possessing a C-23 ketone and a C-26 carboxylic acid, is one of the common features in
Ganoderma
lanostanoids. The absolute configurations of C-25 have not been determined for most of these compounds. Since the C-25 chiral carbon is isolated from the main part of the molecule, assignment of its configuration, relative to the tetracyclic ring and C-20, by NMR techniques is difficult. Additionally, the ECD calculation method would not be suitable for determining the relative configuration, while it is very useful for confirming the absolute configuration of the lanostane skeleton. There have been a few examples of the configuration of C-25 being determined by X-ray crystallographic analysis, and both 24 S - and 25 R -isomers have been reported ( Li et al., 2016 ; Peng et al., 2015 ; Pu et al., 2017 ). It is generally difficult to obtain crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis for this group of compounds. For ganoderic acid A ( 4 ), most literature and web information (e.g., in catalogs as a biochemical reagent) do not show or indicate the 25 R configuration in the depicted chemical structure. We were unable to find literature that describes the determination of the C-25 configuration of ganoderic acid A, except for a recent US patent document that claimed to have a method for the determination of the configuration of ganoderic acid A by X-ray crystallographic analysis (Hsieh, 2019). However, the patent shows a 25 R -isomer in the ORTEP figure, but the 25 S -isomer is depicted as the presented chemical structure. More confusingly, the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data (measured in CDCl 3 ) were apparently different from those reported in the original isolation report ( Kubota et al., 1982 ). NMR spectroscopic data (measured in CDCl 3 ) of compound 4 isolated in the present study from
G. sichuanense
were consistent with those of the original paper. The relative configuration, except for C-25, was confirmed by our own analysis of the 2D NMR spectroscopic data (similar to the structure elucidation of 1 as described above), which also led to the full assignments of protons and carbons ( Table S1 ).

Very recently, we reported the isolation of
Ganoderma
lanostanoids, ganoweberianic acids and ganoweberianones possessing the same type of side chain as ganoderic acid A ( Isaka et al., 2020c ) and determined the 25 S configuration for the most abundant compound, ganoweberianic acid A, by using the PGME method ( Yabuuchi and Kusumi, 2000 ). Therefore, this method was also applied to ganoderic acid A ( 4 ). The Δ δ -values ( δ (S) – δ (R)) obtained from the ( S )- and ( R )-PGME amide derivatives 25a and 25b , respectively, indicated the 25 R configuration of compound 4 ( Fig. 4 ). Consequently, acetonide derivative 1 is also assigned as a 25 R -isomer. The methyl ester of 1 , named methyl ganoderate A acetonide, was previously isolated together with methyl ganoderate A (ganoderic acid A methyl ester) from
G. lucidum
, wherein the configuration of C-25 was not reported ( Lee et al., 2011 ).

In this study, eight other lanostanoids possessing the same C-20–C-27 side chain and close structure of the tetracyclic ring with ganoderic acid A ( 4 ) were isolated: ganoderic acid B ( 5 ) ( Kubota et al., 1982 ), ganoderic acid B8 ( 6 ) ( Kikuchi et al., 1986 ), ganoderic acid C1 ( 7 ) ( Nishitoba et al., 1984 ), ganoderic acid C2 ( 8 ) ( Kikuchi et al., 1986 ), ganoderic acid J ( 9 ) ( Nishitoba et al., 1985 ), ganoderic acid K ( 10 ) ( Kikuchi et al., 1986 ), ganolucidic acid A ( 11 ) ( Kikuchi et al., 1985 ), and ganolucidic acid C ( 12 ) ( Nishitoba et al., 1985 ). To further confirm the C-25 configuration of these compounds, two other major lanostane constituents, 8 and 11 , were also applied with the PGME method. The Δ δ -values ( δ (S) – δ (R)) for PGME amide derivatives 26a / 26b and 27a / 27b ( Fig. 4 ) defined the 25 R configuration of both 8 and 11 , respectively. Each of 4–12 was isolated as a single diastereomer (not as a mixture of C-25 epimers), as confirmed by their NMR spectra. Therefore, it should be safe to conclude that all of them possess the 25 R configuration.
NMR spectroscopic data for compounds 1–3 in CDCl

δ H, mult. ( J in Hz)
δ H, mult. ( J in Hz)

subSection.paragraph: Compound 2 had the molecular formula C 30 H 44 O 6 as determined by HRESIMS. The NMR spectroscopic data of 2 suggested a lanostane skeleton, and its planar structure was deduced from the COSY and HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ). The presence of an α,β- unsaturated carboxylic acid in the side chain was indicated by the HMBC correlations from H-24 and H 3 -27 to the carboxyl carbon ( δ C 171.8, C-26). The 24 E configuration was deduced from the NOESY correlation between Hb- 23 ( δ H 2,26) and H 3 -27 and the absence of the cross-peak for H-24/H 3 -27. The location of a conjugated ketone was revealed by the HMBC correlations from Hα- 12 and Hβ- 12 to the ketone carbon ( δ C 200.3, C-11), from Hα- 1, H-7, and H 3 - 19 to an olefinic carbon ( δ C 139.9, C-9), and from H-7 and H 3 -30 to a downfield olefinic carbon ( δ C 160.1, C-8). The presence of a C-3 ketone was evident from the HMBC correlations from Hα- 1, Hβ- 1, Hα- 2, Hβ- 2, H 3 -28, and H 3 -29 to the ketone carbon ( δ C 218.1, C-3). Two secondary alcohols were assigned to the C-7 and C-22 positions on the basis of the COSY correlations. An equatorial (β) orientation of H-7 was indicated by its small coupling constant values (resonated as a broad singlet) and its NOESY correlations with Hα- 6, Hβ- 6, Hβ- 15, and H 3 -18 (weak). The configuration of C-22 was determined by the modified Mosher’ s method ( Ohtani et al., 1991 ). Compound 2 was converted to its methyl ester and then acylated with Mosher reagents to obtain ( S )- and ( R )-MTPA esters 28a and 28b , respectively ( Fig. 5 ). The Δ δ -values indicated the 7 R , 22 S -configuration of compound 2 , which also confirmed the absolute configuration of the lanostane core, as depicted. In this analysis, only the Δ δ -value for H 3 -30 (+0.05 ppm) was inconsistent with the rule of the modified Mosher’ s method with regard to the discussion of the configuration of C-7. Both H 3 -30 methyl protons were significantly upfield shifted ( 28a , δ H 0.72; 28b , δ H 0.67) when compared with that for 2 ( δ H 1.29). Therefore, this unusual upfield shift was not due to the shielding effect of the phenyl group of 7α- O-MTPA. This can be explained by the much larger shielding effect of H 3 -30 by the carbonyl group of 7α- O-MTPA because of the close placement of the carbonyl π- face to CH 3 -30 and the rigid conformation of the ester. Thus, the Δ δ -value for H 3 -30 could be treated as an exception. Consequently, compound 2 was identified as (22 S ,24 E )-7α,22-dihydroxy-3,11-dioxolanosta-8, 24-dien-26-oic acid.

The molecular formula of compound 3 was determined by HRESIMS to be C 30 H 48 O 4 . The NMR spectra revealed the presence of a ketone, an oxymethine, and two hydroxymethyl groups. The location of the ketone at C-3 was evident from the HMBC correlations from Hβ- 2, H 3 -28, and H 3 -29 to the ketone carbon ( δ C 217.5). The presence of a secondary alcohol at C-7 was revealed by the HMBC correlations from H-5 and Hα- 6 to the oxymethine carbon (C-7) and from H-7 to C-5, C-8, and C-9. The oxymethine proton (H-7) resonated as a broad singlet with a narrow peak width, which indicated small coupling constant values and its equatorial (β) orientation. This was further confirmed by the NOESY correlations of H-7 with both Hα- 6 and Hβ- 6 and a weak correlation with H 3 -18. Two hydroxymethyl groups were located at terminal positions (C-26 and C-27) of the C-20–C-27 side chain, which was demonstrated by the HMBC correlations from H 2 -26 to C-24, C-25, and C-27 and from H 2 -27 to C-24, C-25, and C-26. Therefore, compound 3 was identified as 3-oxo-7α,26,27-trihydroxylanosta-8,24-diene.

We searched for antitubercular and antimalarial drug lead compounds from
Ganoderma
(Isaka et al., 2013, 2017, 2020a). Undescribed compounds 1–3 and selected known lanostanoids ( 4 , 6 , 8 , 11 , and 13–15 ) were tested for activities against
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
H37Ra and
Plasmodium falciparum
K1 (multidrug-resistant strain) and cytotoxicity to nonmalignant Vero cells (African green monkey kidney fibroblasts). Most importantly, ganoderiol F ( 15 ) exhibited potent antitubercular activity with an MIC value of 0.781 μg/ml ( Table 2 ). Other 26,27-diol-type compounds, 3 and ganoderiol B ( 14 ), also showed moderate antitubercular activity (MIC 6.25 μg/ml). We previously reported the antitubercular activities of mycelium-associated
Ganoderma
lanostanoids and proposed their structure-activity relationships (Isaka et al., 2017). It should be noted that the side chain structures of lanostanes 3 , 14 , and 15 , bearing 26,27-diol, are different from those of mycelium-associated antitubercular lanostanes, which possess ( E )-α, β- unsaturated carboxylic acids (same as 2 and 13 ). On the other hand, only ganolucidic acid E ( 13 ) showed antimalarial activity with an IC 50 value of 7.2 μg/ml. Compounds 14 and 15 showed weak cytotoxicity.

The present results further demonstrate the structural diversity and significance of the biological activities of
Ganoderma
lanostanoids. The 25 R configuration of ganoderic acid A and its derivatives were determined by using the PGME method. Taken together with our recent successful results for a 25 S -isomer (ganoweberianic acid A) ( Isaka et al., 2020c ), it can be concluded that Kusumi’ s PGME method performs well for the determination of the absolute configuration at C-25 of major structural groups of
Ganoderma
lanostanoids possessing the same or similar side chain as ganoderic acid A. Potent antitubercular activity of ganoderiol F is noteworthy.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. COSY and HMBC correlations for compounds 1–3 .

subSection.paragraph: Optical rotations were determined using a JASCO P-2000 digital polarimeter. UV spectra were recorded on JASCO V-730 and GBC Cintra 404 spectrophotometers. FTIR spectra were acquired using a Bruker ALPHA spectrometer. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AV500D spectrometer. ESITOF mass spectra were measured using a Bruker micrOTOF mass spectrometer. Merck Silica gel 60H (particle size, 90% < 45 μm) was used for column chromatography.

The fungus used in this study was isolated on unidentified wood in a mixed forest at the University of Phayao Campus , Phayao Province , Thailand , on
July 27, 2012
. The voucher mushroom specimen was deposited in the BIOTEC Bangkok Herbarium as BBH44561 , and the living culture was preserved in the BIOTEC Culture Collection as BCC 55500 . This fungus was identified as
Ganoderma sichuanense J.D. Zhao & X.Q. Zhang (Ganodermataceae)
on the basis of the sequence data of the ITS rDNA (GenBank accession number: MW468666 )
.

subSection.paragraph:
The protocols and production materials for commercial production of the lingzhi medicinal mushroom (
G. lucidum
) by the Arunvik Mushroom Center, a mushroom factory ( Nakhon Pathom , Thailand ), were applied for the fruiting body cultivation of
G. sichuanense
. The mycelia were grown on PDA agar at 25 ◦ C for 15 days. Then, a 1 × 1 cm fungal colony was cut from the agar plate and transferred into a glass bottle containing sterile millet (7 × 17 cm ). After incubation at 25 ◦ C for 14 days, spawn was used as the inoculum for cultivation in 120 substrate bags. Each plastic bag contained ca. 1 kg of substrate consisting of 92.5% (w/w) sawdust, 4.6% (w/w) rice bran, 1.8% (w/w) calcium sulfate, 0.9% calcium oxide, and 0.2% (w/w) magnesium sulfate (purchased from the Arunyik Mushroom Center). The substrate bags were incubated in a cultivation house at 27–30 ◦ C for 21 days for mycelial growth; then, the bags were opened. It required an additional 64 days at 27–30 ◦ C for induction and growth of fruiting bodies. Fruiting bodies of suitable size ( 5–15 cm stalk long) were obtained from all substrate bags and then harvested for further analysis.

Dried fruiting bodies ( 1.17 kg ) were cut into small pieces and extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 (5.0 l) at room temperature for 7 days. The mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure. This extraction procedure was repeated one more time to obtain a CH 2 Cl 2 extract as a dark brown gum (extract A, 27.2 g ). The mushroom residue was then extracted with MeOH (4.0 l, 7 days) to obtain a dark brown gum (extract B, 19.4 g ). The CH 2 Cl 2 extract (extract A) was subjected to column chromatography (CC) on silica gel (5.8 × 16 cm , EtOAc–hexane, step gradient elution 0:100, 20:80, 40:60, 60:40, 80:20, and 100:0, then with acetone) to obtain nineteen fractions, Fr-A1–Fr-A19. Fr-A1–Fr-A3 (total 6.81 g ) were mainly composed of lipids. Fr-A4 ( 0.40 g ), Fr-A5 ( 0.20 g ), and Fr-A6 ( 0.54 g ) were fractionated and purified by preparative HPLC using a reversed-phase column (Waters SunFire Prep C 18 OBD, 19 × 250 mm , 10 μm; mobile phase MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 65:35 to 100:0 over 55 min; flow rate 12 ml/min) to furnish 16 ( 55 mg ), 17 ( 130 mg ), 22 ( 17 mg ), and 23 ( 61 mg ). Fr-A7 ( 1.71 g ), Fr-A8 ( 1.16 g ), and Fr-A9 ( 1.39 g ) were subjected to preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 40:60 to 100:0 over 70 min) to afford 13 ( 116 mg ), 15 ( 11 mg ), 18 ( 26 mg ), 19 ( 77 mg ), 20 ( 40 mg ), and 21 ( 34 mg ). Fr-A10 ( 1.16 g ), Fr-A11 ( 1.17 g ), Fr-A12 ( 0.52 g ) and Fr-A13 ( 1.63 g ) were also fractionated by preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, 40:60 to 100:0 over 40 min) to afford 5 ( 49 mg ), 7 ( 24 mg ), 11 ( 697 mg ), and 24 ( 19 mg ). Fr-A14 ( 2.60 g ) was subjected to CC on Sephadex LH-20 (5.2 × 45 cm , acetone), and the fractions were further separated by preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 35:65 to 70:30 over 40 min) to furnish 2 (6.0 mg), 3 ( 50 mg ), and 9 ( 9.5 mg ). Fr-A15 ( 0.470 g ), Fr-A16 ( 0.640 g ), Fr-A17 ( 1.50 g ), Fr-A18 ( 1.23 g ), and Fr-A19 ( 1.21 g ) were subjected to preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 30:70 to 70:30 over 45 min) to afford 4 ( 512 mg ), 6 ( 191 mg ), 8 ( 429 mg ), 10 ( 27 mg ), and 14 ( 9.1 mg ). The MeOH extract (extract B) was fractionated by silica gel CC (5.8 × 19 cm , acetone–hexane, step gradient elution 0:100, 20:80, 40:60, 60:40, 80:20, and then 100:0) to obtain five fractions, Fr–B1–Fr-B5. Fr-B1 and Fr-B2 (total 1.52 g ) were mainly composed of lipids. Fr-B3 ( 1.61 g ) was purified by preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 40:60 to 80:20 over 40 min) to furnish 1 ( 7.1 mg ) and 11 ( 127 mg ). Fr-B4 ( 1.25 g ) and Fr-B5 ( 0.560 g ) were subjected to preparative HPLC (MeCN–H 2 O, gradient from 25:75 to 65:25 over 45 min) to afford 6 ( 74 mg ), 8 ( 346 mg ), and 12 ( 80 mg ).

paragraph.tableNote: a Standard antituberculosis drug. b Standard antimalarial drug. c Standard compound for the cytotoxicity assay.

subSection.paragraph: Colorless solid; [α] 26 D =+98 ( c 0.36, CHCl 3 ); UV λmax MeOH (nm) (log ε ): 250 (3.89); IR u max ATR (cm 1 ): 1707, 1661; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; HRESIMS ( m/z ): 555.3320 [M ‒ H] ‒ (calc. for C 33 H 47 O 7 , 555.3327).

Colorless solid; [α] 26 D = +136 ( c 0.29, CHCl 3 ); UV λmax MeOH (nm) (log ε ): 215 (4.00), 250 (3.77); IR u max ATR (cm 1 ): 3427, 1696, 1650; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; HRESIMS ( m/z ): 523.3039 [M + Na] + (calc. for C 30 H 44 O 6 Na, 523.3030).

Colorless solid; [α] 25 D = +100 ( c 0.23, CHCl 3 ); UV λmax MeOH (nm) (log ε ): 202 (4.19), 235 (3.29), 243 (3.24), 253 (3.11); IR u max ATR (cm 1 ): 3392, 1698; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; 13 C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table 1 ; HRESIMS ( m/z ): 495.3446 [M +Na] + (calc. for C 30 H 48 O 4 Na, 495.3445).

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Synthesis of 1 from ganoderic acid A (4)

subSection.paragraph: To a solution of compound 4 ( 3.2 mg ) in 2,2-dimethoxypropane (0.5 ml) was added p -TsOH⋅H 2 O (ca. 1 mg ), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The mixture was diluted with H 2 O (1 ml) and extracted with EtOAc (2 ml, twice). The organic layer was washed with saturated aqueous NaCl (1 ml) and concentrated under reduced pressure to give the acetonide derivative ( 2.7 mg , 79%), whose NMR and HRESIMS data were consistent with those of natural product 1 .

heading.emphasis: 4.5. Preparation of (S)- and (R)-PGME amides (25a and 25b) of ganoderic acid A (4)

subSection.paragraph:
To a solution of ganoderic acid A ( 4 , 10.4 mg , 0.020 mmol), ( S )- phenylglycine methyl ester hydrochloride (( S )-PGME‧HCl, 8.4 mg , 0.040 mmol), and 4-(dimethylamino)pyridine (DMAP, 5.9 mg , 0.048 mmol) in CH 2 Cl 2 (0.8 ml) was added a solution of N -(dimethylaminopropyl)-
N ʹ
-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC‧HCl, ca. 8 mg , ca. 0.04 mmol) in CH 2 Cl 2 (0.8 ml), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. The solution was diluted with EtOAc (6 ml) and washed successively with 1 M HCl (2 ml, three times) and saturated aqueous NaHCO 3 (2 ml). The organic layer was concentrated under reduced pressure to obtain a colorless gum, which was purified by silica gel CC (1.2 × 10 cm , MeOH/ CH 2 Cl 2 , 3:97) to furnish ( S )-PGME amide 25a ( 12.3 mg , 92%). Similarly, ( R )-PGME amide 25b ( 12.5 mg , 94%) was prepared from 4 and ( R )-PGME‧HCl.

Colorless gum; IR u max ATR (cm 1 ): 3339, 1746, 1706, 1663; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table S1 ; 13 C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table S1 ; HRESIMS ( m/z ): 662.3694 [M ‒ H] ‒ (calc. for C 39 H 52 NO 8 , 662.3698).

Colorless gum; IR u max ATR (cm 1 ): 3361, 1745, 1707, 1666; 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table S1 ; 13 C NMR (125 MHz, CDCl 3 ) data, Table S1 ; HRESIMS ( m/z ): 662.3699 [M ‒ H] ‒ (calc. for C 39 H 52 NO 8 , 662.3698).

heading.emphasis: 4.6. Preparation of (S)- and (R)-PGME amides of ganoderic acid C2 and ganolucidic acid A

subSection.paragraph: To a solution of ganoderic acid C2 ( 8 , 2.6 mg , 0.005 mmol), ( S )- PGME‧HCl ( 2.1 mg , 0.01 mmol), and DMAP ( 1.5 mg , 0.012 mmol) in CH 2 Cl 2 (0.4 ml) was added a solution of EDC‧HCl (ca. 2 mg , ca. 0.01 mmol) in CH 2 Cl 2 (0.2 ml), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 40 min. The solution was diluted with EtOAc (6 ml) and washed successively with 1 M HCl (2 ml, three times) and saturated aqueous NaHCO 3 (2 ml). The organic layer was concentrated under reduced pressure to obtain ( S )-PGME amide 26a ( 2.9 mg ). Similarly, PGME amides 26b ( 3.1 mg ), 27a (3.0 mg), and 27b (3.0 mg) were prepared. The purities of these crude reaction products were sufficient for 1 H NMR (CDCl 3 , 500 MHz) spectroscopic analysis. Partial assignments of protons, including those of the C-20–C-27 side chain, were achieved by analysis of the COSY data.

heading.emphasis: 4.7. Synthesis of the mosher ester derivatives 28a and 28b

subSection.paragraph: To a solution of 2 (2.0 mg) in CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (1:1, 0.2 ml) was added a solution of (trimethylsilyl)diazomethane in hexane (0.6 M, 100 μl), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1.5 h. The reaction was quenched by the addition of AcOH (50 μl), and then two drops of ammonia solution were added. The mixture was concentrated under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved in EtOAc and washed with H 2 O and saturated aqueous NaCl. The organic layer was concentrated under reduced pressure to furnish the methyl ester derivative (2.0 mg, colorless gum): 1 H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl 3 ) δ 6.79 (1H, m, H-24), 4.47 (1H, br s, H-7), 3.84 (1H, m, H-22), 3.75 (3H, s, 26-OCH 3 ), 2.99 (1H, m, Hβ- 1), 2.72 (1H, d, J =17.6 Hz, Hα- 12), 2.62 (1H, m, Hβ- 2), 2.48 (1H, d, J = 17.8 Hz, Hβ- 12), 2.48 (1H, m, Ha- 23), 2.45 (1H, m, Hα- 2), 2.23 (1H, m, Hb- 23), 2.18 (1H, m, H-17), 2.13 (1H, m, Hβ- 16), 2.09 (1H, m, H-5), 1.93 (1H, m, Hβ- 15), 1.87 (3H, s, H-27), 1.76–1.68 (4H, m, Hα-1 , Hα- 6, Hβ- 6, and Hα- 15), 1.46 (1H, m, H-20), 1.45 (1H, m, Hα- 16), 1.29 (3H, s, H-30), 1.15 (3H, s, H-28), 1.08 (3H, s, H-29), 1.04 (3H, s, H-19), 0.91 (3H, d, J = 6.8 Hz, H-21), 0.81 (3H, s, H-18); HRESIMS ( m/z ) 537.3189 [M + Na] + (calc. for C 31 H 46 O 6 Na, 537.3187). A portion ( 0.7 mg ) of the methyl ester was treated with ()-( R )-MTPA-Cl (10 μl) and DMAP ( 10 mg ) in CH 2 Cl 2 (0.2 ml) at room temperature for 2 days. The mixture was diluted with EtOAc and washed with H 2 O, 1 M HCl (three times), and then with saturated aqueous NaHCO 3 (three times), and the organic layer was concentrated in vacuo to obtain a pale yellow gum, which was purified by preparative HPLC (MeCN/H 2 O) to furnish bis-( S )- MTPA ester 28a ( 0.5 mg ). Similarly, bis-( R )-MTPA ester 28b was prepared from the methyl ester derivative and (+)-( S )-MTPA-Cl. Assignments of protons were achieved by analysis of the COSY and NOESY data.

Antimycobacterial activity against
Mycobacterium tuberculosis
H37Ra was evaluated using the green fluorescent protein microplate assay (Changsen et al., 2003). Antiplasmodial activity against
Plasmodium falciparum
(K1, multidrug resistant strain) was performed in duplicate using the microculture radioisotope technique (Desjardins et al., 1979). Cytotoxicity to Vero cells was evaluated using the green fluorescent protein microplate assay (Hunt et al., 1999).
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
